title: Honeywell, Lockheed Boost Their Stocks’ Dividends
text:
Text size

Lockheed Martin’s fourth-quarter dividend will be $2.40 a share, up from $2.20. Here, a Lockheed-built fighter jet.

Two well-known U.S. companies declared dividend increases this past week.

Honeywell International (ticker: HON), a manufacturing conglomerate whose products include thermostats, auxiliary power units for airplanes and specialty chemicals, on Friday declared an annual dividend of $3.60 a share.

That’s up nearly 10% from $3.28. On a quarterly basis, it will be 90 cents a share starting in the fourth quarter.

The stock, which yields 2%, has a one-year return of about 8%.

Based in Charlotte, N.C., the company has used its industrial and manufacturing roots to migrate more into software development.

Separately, Lockheed Martin (LMT) on Thursday said it will pay a fourth-quarter dividend of $2.40 a share. That’s 9% above the current quarterly payout of $2.20 a share offered by the Bethesda, Md.-based defense contractor.

The stock, which yields 2.2%, has a one-year return of about 15%, compared with 4% for the S&P 500.

Write to Lawrence C. Strauss at lawrence.strauss@barrons.com
description: Manufacturing conglomerate Honeywell boosted its payout by 10%, while defense contractor Lockheed raised its dividend 9%.
